content.description:
An old-fashioned mountaineering route - a lot of class 3, with a few pitches of 5th class.

Find the lower end of the obvious ramp system and scramble up until you meet 5th class terrain.  Before you rope up you have the option of passing over or under a small buttress - either works.

Climb two pitches of 5th class terrain.  The crux comes near the top of the second pitch.  We moved out onto the face to the right, where the rock looked better.  (Straight up the corner looked a bit loose.)

Beyond is mostly 2nd to 4th class terrain, with one or two brief (20-40 foot) sections of 5th class.  The first of these came after turning a corner and finding a few thin moves up a short slab.  The second comes as you exit Wandering Spirit, moving around a drippy corner and up toward the sunny top out.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Nuts and small cams were useful in the crux.  Larger cams (to 3 or 4 inches) were useful on the easier terrain.
content.location: Cross the isthums between the lakes and wander up through the boulders.  A little left from the lowest point of the wall you will find an easy entrance to the ramp system.

content.description:
A wonderful slanting dihedral that yields a variation on the lower half of Wandering Spirit.

This route is mainly defined by the obvious dihedral to the right of the crux pitches of Wandering Spirit.  Your first goal is to get to the base of this dihedral.

We began at a low angle slab that gave access to a series of corners connecting benches.  The second bench gave us a long traverse into the dihedral.  Take care in these initial corners.  Most of the rock was clean and solid, but the second corner was loose and dropped a rock that trapped my finger while on lead- it was a struggle to free my hand again.

Two rope lengths put us in the middle of the traverse to the dihedral.  There are potentially three ways into the dihedral, and we took the middle way up a chimney.  There is a huge, hidden crack in the main wall as you step into the chimney that makes this an easy proposition, even if you have no chimney technique.

A little further is the crux.  All the holds seem to be on the overhanging left wall, while the slabby right wall is smooth.  We found plenty of pro through here, and with a well-placed hip or shoulder you can find many "rests".  Pull through a gap in the overhang on big, juggy holds.

We belayed here just above the overhang, where we could get our feet under us, to avoid rope drag.  The upper part of the dihedral eases off, except for the exit moves at the top.  Exit left and you are in the slabby terrain that is next to the crux of Wandering Spirit.  Continue up to the ramp system to top out.
content.protection: Standard rack, nuts and small cams to big cams.
content.location: From the lowest point of Spiderweb Wall, walk up and right to the slabby start.

content.description:
Break through the roof, then fire straight up the line of weakness.

See

Lost Twin Lakes: A Little Known Alpine Wall Gets Six Long New Routes (AAJ 2017)
content.location: Toward the right edge of Spiderweb Wall.  Tops out where Wandering Spirit ends.
